title: Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp spells out just why he LOVES their captain Jordan Henderson
text:
Sport Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp spells out just why he LOVES their captain Jordan Henderson The England midfielder has been asked to play a different position for the German and has taken to it like a duck to water Share Boss Klopp sounds this close to asking Henderson for his autograph (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! For someone once dismissed by Sir Alex Ferguson as a player who couldn’t run , Jordan Henderson has been doing a lot of it this season. 
Henderson is the Premier League’s most important midfielder, the man who has completed most passes and run the greatest distance in the division... while proving himself most valuable to his team. 
That is why his Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp openly admits “I love his attitude”, and also concedes that his team may have relied too much on their skipper this season — a fact perhaps proven as they failed to win either of their last two matches, away to Sunderland in the league and at Southampton in the EFL Cup, when he was missing. 
Certainly, Klopp will be praying his captain will be back for the visit to the lion’s den of Old Trafford on Sunday, because he knows he will need the energy and defensive intelligence of his England star to curb the attacking threat of Paul Pogba. For Klopp, it is Henderson’s ability to adapt from an attacking player himself, to one who has performed the defensive role better this season than anyone – better even than last season’s best midfielder, N’Golo Kante, as data provided by EA Sports show. 
“He adapted unbelievably good to the position, so for us he is very important. Maybe we relied too much on him,” the German coach admitted. 
“I don’t read what you write, so if there is not enough credit for him then do it! 
“He can’t have any more credit in my eyes. I love his attitude – it is outstanding.” Ex-United boss Ferguson's autobiography included a bizarre criticism of Henderson (Photo: Getty) 
For his manager, it is Henderson’s appetite for the game and willingness to not only learn but sacrifice himself for the team that is the key. 
He was good enough in a more advanced midfield position to become an England regular, but when his new club boss said he needed to drop deeper to become Liverpool’s anchor, the 26-year-old agreed readily. 
Indeed, it is that approach and desire which Klopp suggests is the only reason Henderson has a chance of playing at Old Trafford.
